user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
  /* Do not use sysctl() function on GNU/Linux even if
     sysctl() is available */
#ifndef __linux__
#ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.ncpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPU};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU */
#endif /* ! __linux__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call sysctl(mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0) passes mib (an int[2] decaying to int *) to sysctl. MISRA Rule 8.13 urges pointers to point to const-qualified types when possible; however the system prototype of sysctl declares the name parameter as int * (non-const). Because the external API does not accept a const-qualified pointer and the mib array is not modified by the code, the code cannot reasonably make mib const without conflicting with the sysctl declaration. Therefore no MISRA 8.13 violation in this code fragment.
